It may take her many years to fully understand herself - to have the luxury of being able to lay down the protective mantle of stoicism takes a certain courage and humility within oneself, as well as freedom of the spirit, which very few of us could achieve while living in constant fear.

There but for the grace of God go I. As a young photojournalist who went to El Salvador in 1981, I believed that telling the truth would achieve something and that I could make a difference. I believed in the power of the press over politics. Either way, better to be hopeful if naive instead of cynical - otherwise the world will never see attempts to improve it.

As someone who grew up in Guatemala at the height of Gatemala's civil war in the 70s-80s I have absolutely no sympathy for Lori Berenson. Her involvement in Sendero Luminoso a Maoist terrorist group only led to more death and suffering of Peruvians than any improvement in the lot of impoverished Peruvians. In fact I will state their very actions only worsened their lot.

In fact I will also state that all too many so called communist liberation groups proved once in power to be far more dictatorial than those they displaced however bloody they may have been. In fact I will also note that the aggregate death toll inflicted by communist states on their own citizens in the twentieth century exceeds that inflicted by fascist states. Those like Lori Berenson who romanticize and choose to participate in the bloody and atrocity laden conflict caused by so called liberators are not worthy of any respect or sympathy when they finally have to face he consequences of their actions. Lori Berenson choose her path, and now she should accept and face the consequences of her actions. She also owes an apology for her role in aiding and abetting Sendero Luminoso's bloody attacks to those who were victims of them. Nor is she worthy of been called saintly.

I understand the chosen tone of the author in trying to highlight the human aspects of Ms. Berenson' struggle while in jail. However, one detail the author did not mention was that the hooded judges used during that time to try terrorism suspects in Peru had to do it because many of them had been assassinated. A review of newspapers of the 80s and early 90s will show that. The fact is that both MRTA and Shinning Path were criminal associations that used brutal violence as their way to get their goals against a democratic society. No society in this planet needs to see this type of violence again.

Even though Peru is a young democracy and still shows several social and economic gaps, Peruvians have demonstrated they could sack a corrupt government peacefully as they did when they sacked Alberto Fujimori in the early 2000s.

I have followed Lori Berenson's plight from the very beginning and I have always wondered at the pain her parents must have felt.
She has served more than her time, more time than others who committed murder. Now she needs to come home.
What impressed me most about her is the complete absence of faulting other people-so different from others in similar positions. I also admire her sister for not exposing their shared family life with the whole world. With reality T.V. and so many memoirs, it is great to see that someone wants to keep it to themselves.
I wish Lori, Salvador, her sister and her parents many years of shared happiness. They deserve it.

About 30 years ago, I got lost on the Long Island Beltway. I pulled off the freeway to ask for directions. I pulled into one gasoline station and asked for directions and the attendant just ignored me. After driving around looking for another gas station and getting more lost, I was finally in tears. I pulled into another station, balling my eyes out. The young attendant, a black fellow, was gassing up another customer. He saw me crying and asked me what was the matter. I blubbered out: I'm lost! He said: Don't worry, as soon as I am done here, I will help you and you won't be lost no more. Words like the balm of Gilead on my head. Calmed me right down. And true to his words, he told me how to get back on track.
I never did find out his name, but to this day, I ask God to bless that man for the beautiful kindness he showed me that day.

RoseFitz, I mourn that building and find it breathtakingly peculiar that such a wonderful, ancient structure was bypassed by multiple preservation groups pursuing far less memorable things.  It wasn't so much that they ignored it -- they were blind to it.  The same happened with the Weyhe Gallery on Lexington and 62nd [http://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/29/realestate/streetscapes-the-weyhe-book-store-and-gallery-from-books-to-baked-goods.html], and the startling little International Style building on 57th and Lexington [http://www.nytimes.com/1999/03/07/realestate/streetscapes-readers-questions-dad-s-house-stanford-white-design-swami-s-visit.html].  For me, the lesson is that it doesn't really matter how "good" a building is,  if it doesn't have a constituency -- most often surrounding residential buildings -- you can more often than not just write it off.

I think the timing of Rep. King's hearings and the current crisis in the Middle East stinks.

We have a series of Islamic countries that is in effect changing socially and politically, being influenced by the work of an American writer of political theory based on non-violence and democracy, while we have an American Congressional Representative having hearings that are going to be testing the loyalty of people living in this country. How is this going to affect countries going through the embryonic stage of creating a new government going to feel that people, who they feel like extended relatives, being put through a process that looks like they're being prosecuted because of Islam.

This is a bad idea, especially after two years ago, President Obama announced that America wanted a new relationship with Islam.

The President can not sit idly by and just have Rep. King go through with these hearings - it's not only a waste of government funds, as well hypocritical to Republican calls for reining in spending, but what could be a possible foreign policy problem that hasn't been seen since George W. Bush, and a possible embarrassing point of contention for the President in the Middle East.

I applauded Jim McMahon when he played football.  I wasn't in a position to know what he did or didn't do or when and how much BYU knew when.  I was at BYU during McMahon's time and I know the Honor Code was enforced.  If McMahon broke the code he only injured his own character.  I forgive him, but I think much more highly of Brandon Davies than him.

These hearings need to be expanded to include all forms of violent extremism facing the American public.  And I can guarantee that if the committee starts investigating white supremacist groups, I will not, as a Caucasian American, be asked to "publicly condemn" the actions of my fellow Caucasians, simply because I share the same skin color and European ancestry.  Similarly, my Muslim husband should not be exhorted to publicly condemn the actions of Muslim extremists simply because he is one of over a billion human beings who happen to share the same religion.  Collective guilt does not work.  We can all, as human beings, condemn violence, wherever and however it exists.

I am glad if Italian football is losing its shine. Italy is my least favorite team to watch - they have made a business of making a mockery of the beautiful game. Year after year, the Italian team has been just 'tactical' - code for scoring one goal and then falling in defense. They have shamelessly used any possible 'gamesmanship' to win games - diving by Italian players and the ensuing histrionics are sometimes Oscar worthy.Their success in world football has cemented such gamesmanship in the game, they have now been ingrained in the DNA of football and I blame the Italians for degrading the quality of the game and letting down billions of fans worldwide. I sincerely hope Serie A teams get hammered by free flowing attacking soccer teams like Barcelona that advance the game and win by fair means.

Continued from Hans #5, #6 and #11:

I think I have proved that C_2 is the longest lace cycle satisfying Q3. I am able to show the longest diagonals (1,1) (4,2) and (4,1) (1,2) have to be an edge in the cycle. I have dropped the arrows since the direction is not important here. Then all 4 diagonals traverses 2 vertical eyelet spacings have to be present as edges as well. Finally, the only way to complete a cycle is to connect (2,1) with (2,2), and (3,1) with (3,2).

The proof is a bit complicated especially when I can only use words. Of course, that is what a rigorous proof should be, using only symbols (words), a la Hilbert program.

Like the proof for C_1 being the shortest cycle I alluded to Hans #11, it requires a classification of all possible patterns of the neighbouring edges (the straight lace segments going in and out of) of two vertices (eyelets) on the same side of the shoe. Then apply the reverse of the replacement strategy I, Hans #16, and Richardo Ech, #15, alluded to.

I may write out an outline of the proof later should time allow.

Additional note:

The classification is to ensure the replacement operation will preserve the structure of a complete cycle.

Reduce the trade deficit; increase GDP & median wage

Warren Buffett’s concept to significantly reduce USA’s trade deficit.

It is not our global trade but our trade deficits’ that are a significant net detriment to our economy. Trade deficits’ amount of detriment to their nations’ GDPs are significantly larger than the deficits themselves.

I’m a proponent of a proposal to reduce USA’s trade deficit of goods that was first introduced to the Senate in 2006. This simple concept is not simplistic and is worthy of consideration.

The basic concept is for exporters who choose to pay the federal fees to acquire transferable IMPORT Certificates for the assessed value of their goods leaving the USA. Importers would be required to surrender IMPORT Certificates for the assessed value of their goods entering the USA. Surrendered certificates are cancelled.

This trade policy would significantly decrease USA’s trade deficit of goods and increase the aggregate sum of USA’s imports plus exports. It can be drafted to be completely self funding. It would not require any additional federal spending, taxes or debt. The version of this trade policy I advocate would exclude scarce or rare minerals integral to goods from the goods’ total assessed values.

Regardless of how small the additions to imports’ prices due to Import Certificates, (unlike tariffs) USA’s assessed imports could never exceed that of our total exports.

Refer to: www.USA-Trade-Deficit.Blogspot.com and
http://en.wikipedia.org...
Respectfully, BB

National trade surpluses’ contributions or trade deficits’ detriments to their nations’ GDPs are always understated.

They’re understated to the extent that any goods or service products which support or were induced by the production of globally traded products but are not reflected within the prices of such products are not attributed to global trade. But all production does contribute to the producing nations’ GDPs.

USA’s trade deficit denied our nation the production of the products we imported. To the extent that production of goods and service products were not reflected within the prices of USA’s imports, we were additionally denied the infrastructures, the knowledge and experience gained due to the production of USA’s imports, any research, development or other goods and service products that supported or were induced by the production of USA’s imports.

These productions and all of the jobs associated to these productions fully contributed to the nations that produced USA’s imported products.

Respectfully, BB
Manners define "us" as less ugly than "them."

"Manners Makyth Man" was a favorite saying of William of Wykeham (1324-1486), who founded New College at Oxford in 1379. "Manners Makyth Man" is displayed above its entrance. For the past hundred years, it has also been the motto of Sydney Technical High School, which not only turns boys into budding scientists and engineers but turns larrikins into polite professionals. That motto has been a constant reminder to behave well.
